definition: morning exercises (physical exercises commonly performed en masse at schools and workplaces in East Asian countries)
to grasp/to hold/to operate/to manage/to control/to steer/to exercise/to drill (practice)/to play/to speak (a language)

sentences.english: Most schools give the students the order that they must do morning exercise together.
sentences.chinese: 大部分学校要求学生必须集体做早操。

sentences.english: He has become lazy about doing morning exercises.
Doing morning exercises is good for us.
Morning excises help us to get ready for the day.
sentences.chinese: 早操有助于我们为一天做好准备。

sentences.english: They sing songs together every morning. We do morning exercises.
sentences.chinese: 他们每天早上都会一起唱歌，我们是做早操。

sentences.english: After running I have to do morning exercises on the playground.
sentences.chinese: 跑完步后我要在操场上做早操。

sentences.english: I do early  sorry every day, so that I can have strong body to prot ect you.
sentences.chinese: 我每天都做早操，这样我会有强壮的身体来保护你。

sentences.english: I do early **** every day,so that I can have strong body to protect you.
sentences.chinese: 我每天都做早操，这样我会有强壮的身体来保护你。

sentences.english: He found a lot of people doing morning exercise there.
sentences.chinese: 他发现许多人在那做早操。

sentences.english: They do morning exercises every day.
Doing morning exercises is of good health.
sentences.chinese: 做早操对你的健康有利。

sentences.english: I do early ---- every day, so that I can have strong body to protect you.
sentences.chinese: 我天天都做早操，这样我会有强健的身材来维护你。

sentences.english: The students laid away their books to do morning exercises.
sentences.chinese: 学生们收拾起书本做早操。

sentences.english: We do morning exercises every day.
The students do morning exercises at six.
While they are doing morning exercises, it suddenly shower.
sentences.chinese: 当他们正在做早操时，突然下了阵雨。

definition: setting-up exercises during the break (between classes)
to drill/to exercise/to go outdoors for physical exercise
matins/morning service (in the Catholic Church)/morning chorus (of birds)
to raise a flag/to hoist a flag
to go to class/to attend class/to go to teach a class
military practice, esp. for reservists or new recruits/military training as a (sometimes compulsory) subject in schools and colleges/drill
to run/to jog/(military) to march at the double
